contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox disease | Name = XX male syndrome | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = ({{ICD10|Q|98|3|q|90}}) | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = 278850 | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }} '''XX male syndrome''' (also called '''de la Chapelle syndrome''', for a researcher who characterized it in 1972<ref>{{cite journal | author=de la Chapelle A | title=Analytic review: nature and origin of males with XX sex chromosomes | journal=Am J Hum Genet | year=1972 | pages=71–105 | volume=24 | issue=1 | pmid=4622299 | pmc=1762158}}</ref>) is a rare sex chromosomal disorder. Usually it is caused by unequal [[Chromosomal crossover|crossing over]] between [[X chromosome|X]] and [[Y chromosome]]s during [[meiosis]] in the father, which results in the X chromosome containing the normally-male [[SRY]] gene. When this X combines with a normal X from the mother during fertilization, the result is an XX male. This syndrome occurs in approximately four or five in 100,000 individuals, making it less common than [[Klinefelter syndrome]].<ref name="pmid17579198">{{cite journal |author=Vorona E, Zitzmann M, Gromoll J, Schüring AN, Nieschlag E |title=Clinical, endocrinological, and epigenetic features of the 46,XX male syndrome, compared with 47,XXY Klinefelter patients |journal=J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. |volume=92 |issue=9 |pages=3458–65 |year=2007 |month=September |pmid=17579198 |doi=10.1210/jc.2007-0447 |url=http://jcem.endojournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17579198}}</ref><ref>http://www.healthline.com/galecontent/xx-male-syndrome Healthline.com: XX Male Syndrome</ref> ==Presentation== Symptoms usually include small [[testes]] and subjects are invariably [[infertility|sterile]]. Individuals with this condition sometimes have feminine characteristics, with varying degrees of [[gynecomastia]] but with no intra-abdominal [[Müllerian duct|Müllerian tissue]].<ref name="pmid5501706" /> According to research at the [[University of Oklahoma]] health science centers, most XX males are not stereotypically feminine and are typical boys and men{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} although other reports suggest that facial hair growth is usually poor and libido is diminished, with notable exceptions.<ref name="pmid5501706">{{cite journal |author=Lisker R, Flores F, Cobo A, Rojas FG |title= A case of XX male syndrome |journal=J. Med. Genet. |volume= 7 |issue= 4 |pages= 394–398 |year= 1970 |month=December |pmid=5501706 |doi=10.1136/jmg.7.4.394 |pmc=1468937}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Abusheikha N, Lass A, Brinsden P|title= Case Report: XX male without SRY gene and with infertility|journal=Human Reproduction |volume= 16 |issue= 4 |pages= 717–718 |year= 2001|url=http://humrep.oxfordjournals.org/content/16/4/717.full.pdf |doi=10.1093/humrep/16.4.717 |pmid=11278224 }}</ref> ==Clinical diagnosis== * Standard XX [[karyotype]] in two tissues (with at least one, or both, containing the male [[SRY]] gene) * Male external genitalia, sometimes showing [[hypospadias]] * Two testes which may or may not have descended the [[inguinal canal]]. Most XX males have descended testes. * Absence of Müllerian tissue ==Pathophysiology== Males typically have one X chromosome and one Y chromosome in each [[diploid]] cell of their bodies. Females typically have two X chromosomes. XX males have two X chromosomes, with one of them containing genetic material from the Y chromosome, making them phenotypically male; they are genetically female but otherwise appear to be male. ==See also== *[[Karyotype]] *[[Swyer syndrome]] *[[X chromosome]], for other diseases related to the X chromosome. *[[Androgen insensitivity syndrome|Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome]] *[[XY female syndrome]] ==External links== * [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1416/ GeneReviews/NCBI/NIH/UW entry on 46,XX Testicular Disorder of Sex Development] * [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1547/ GeneReviews/NCBI/NIH/UW entry on 46,XY Disorder of Sex Development and 46,XY Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis] ==References== {{reflist}} {{disease-stub}} {{Chromosomal abnormalities}} [[Category:Sex chromosome aneuploidies]] [[Category:Intersexuality]] [[Category:Syndromes]]
